title: After Banning Vet Over Neck Tattoo, Bar Finds Out TRUE Meaning
text:
No “Buyer’s Remorse” Among Trump Voters in New Poll 
“I think it’s a ridiculous policy and I think it’s discrimination against some really good people,” Andrus said. 
Managers from the Whiskey Row in Gilbert agreed. They called Andrus and personally apologized . What’s more, the parent company also posted an apology and stated that it was looking into amending the tattoo and dress code policy. 
Now the establishment will be working with police to identify “the difference between gang and non-gang related tattoos.” 
Moore also commented that the company values veterans and all those who have served. Now Whisky Row in Gilbert is planning a “Veterans Appreciation Day” on Wednesday. Proceeds will go to the Wounded Warriors Project. 
As for Andrus, he was happy with the company’s quick response. “They’re going to be a lot of people that are able to go in there now … that wouldn’t be beforehand,” he said. 
That’s how you apologize and really show that your company has learned from its mistake.
